node.title: is there the possibility of Arc_length method in moose ?
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose's developers,
I thought I am not deep familiar with moose,

I wanna ask a short question, is there a specific module for Arc_length method instead of disp-control solver?

if yes, could I study some examples ?
It is important for unloading process in damage.
Thanks,
TAN

This feature is coming in the next PETSc release.
https://gitlab.com/petsc/petsc/-/merge_requests/7502

hi, jed, Thanks for your reply. I will go deep into it.
tianwen.

@jedbrown hi. jed. Here is a updated problem.
Is there any "input" file example for using the Arc-Length method from PETSc within MOOSE ? Thanks.
I tried some, I just changed the "SNES" solver in MOOSE input file to NEWTONAL, but, the PETSc error occured.
what's I should do for this interface ?
Thanks, looking forward to your reply.
tianwen
The example is src/snes/tutorials/ex16.c for that MR. If you have an example, we could test it.

node.title: Not a registered object
node.bodyText:

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question

 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello, I modified a postprocessor object and compiled it susccessfully. I used it yesterday but when I open my application to run the same script today I get this error.
A 'ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor_new' is not a registered object.check_inp(moose_srv)
If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically loaded library, make sure thatcheck_inp(moose_srv)
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in thecheck_inp(moose_srv)
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

I even changed the name of the object and compiled it successfully. It did not work.

Hello
Use MooseApp for the app to register the object to, then recompile
Hello!could you please describe how to do this in detai?

at the top of any source file, there is a call to
registerMooseObject("MiscApp", ThermoDiffusion);

the first one is the app name, the second the object name.
The app name has to be exact. Any typo or capitalization error, and the code wont recognize where the object is coming from

A 'ThermalDiffusion' is not a registered object.

node.title: coupled vector neighbor variable

node.bodyText:
Hello
You have to use the functor APIs (see MooseFunctor.h) to couple finite element variables into finite volume. We do not have the right level of support in the coupleable API at the moment
Guillaume
That problem has solved. There Is no Fv variable. I want to solve same PDE with DGKernel, so this is new.

when are you checking this? The vector is only sized properly inside the assmebly (residual and Jacobian) loops.
and what does the header look like? You need to have stored this by reference
I have put the head at the start. I have used reference.

I have solved it. Thanks.
Maybe I make a stupid error.
The diffusivity is a variable value. I write in the input by following
diffusivity = 1e-12

node.title: Compute Crystal Plasticity Thermal Eigenstrain
node.bodyText:
@sapitts I just had a couple of questions about the compute crystal plasticity thermal eigenstrain.
First is the temperature in Kelvin or degrees Celsius (I have assumed it's Kelvin)
Why is the stress output in the ''multiple_eigenstrains_test_out.csv'' negative(compressive)? My initial thought is that the domain wants to expand due to the thermal expansion coefficient being applied, and there are restricted boundaries that may cause compressive forces. However, the top and right boundaries are free of displacement and allow deformation, so I am kind of confused.
Lastly, why is the eigenstrain_deformation_gradient more than one isn't that more than 100% eigen strain contribution in the system?
I checked the referenced papers, but could not get any substantial evidence.
Any help?

Hi @Emmanuel-324,
You are correct, the default temperature units are Kelvin.
The mesh in the multiple_eigenstrains_test.i is constrained on both the front and back in the z-direction, and so the compressive stress (and strain) will come from these boundary conditions. In this case the eigenstrains introduce a 3D volume change in the lattice, and the crystal must accommodate this increase in volume due to the eigenstrain with a comparative decrease in the crystal volume: this crystal volume change corresponds to a negative strain and a negative stress.
For the deformation gradient, recall the definition of the deformation gradient: the sum of the identity tensor and the partial derivative of the displacement with respect to the reference frame:
$$\mathbf{F} = \mathbf{I} + \frac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial \mathbf{X}} $$
With this definition in mind, we know that a deformation gradient diagonal component (i.e. $F_{ii}$) in the absence of displacement will be equal to 1 (from the identity tensor). Tensile displacement is reflected as a deformation gradient value greater than 1.0; compressive displacement is reflected as a deformation gradient value less than 1.0.
See this website for a review of the deformation gradient definition and a few 2D examples of calculating the deformation gradient: https://www.continuummechanics.org/deformationgradient.html

Thanks for the explanation and the resource.
Below are some relevant snippets of my scrip
[Mesh]
  [file]
     type = FileMeshGenerator
     file = Conc1_out.e-s123
     use_for_exodus_restart = true
   []
 []

[Variables]
   [./disp_x]
   [../]
   [./disp_y]
   [../]
 
   # order parameter 0
   [./eta0]
     initial_from_file_var = eta1
   [../]
   # order parameter 1
   [./eta1]
     initial_from_file_var = eta3
   [../]
 []
[Functions]
  [temperature_function]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'if(t < 0.002, 300 * t / 0.002, 300)'
  []
 [] 
 [BCs]
  [symmy]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  
  [symmx]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
  [tdisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = right
    function = 0.1*t
  []
 []
 [eigenstrain_0]
    type = ComputeCrystalPlasticityThermalEigenstrain
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain_0
    deformation_gradient_name = deformation_gradient_1
    temperature = temperature
    thermal_expansion_coefficients = '1.2e-05 2e-05 3e-05'
    base_name = phase0
  []

[Kernels]
   [./eta0_dt]
     type = TimeDerivative
     variable = eta0
   [../]
   [./eta1_dt]
     type = TimeDerivative
     variable = eta1
   [../]
   [./TensorMechanics]
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
      add_variables = true
      generate_output = stress_xx
      strain = FINITE
   []
 []

I have this crystal plasticity script above that has some of the results below:




I kept the temperature constant because that was not the focus. I only need the eigen contribution.
My first question is to confirm whether how I calculated my eingenstrain for the plots above is correct. I did it as show in the picture below:
.
My second question: Yes my assumption for the compressive stress was because of the boundary conditions as you said. However, after applying displacement in the x direction of my script even though the temperature was constant the graph(Stress vs time) sees the plot moving from compressive to tensile stress—any reason why would be helpful.
Lastly, when I run my script without displacement the computational time is minimal (it takes about 2 hours to get to 100s), but when I add the displacement factor the same script takes about 3 days to get to a timestep of 12.6s. Is there a way I can improve on this?
is the "displacement factor" the constant eigenstrain?
The constant eigenstrain is due to the constant temperature and the same expansion coefficient in both x and y. The displacement factor is for the plastic deformation in the crystal plasticity model.

node.title: Modeling open water bodies
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
i'm doing a model where i have groundwater flow with an open water body an they are in an exchange. Right now i try to model the open water body within PorousFlow and the necessary materials. But im running into Problems with my pore- and gaspressures while trying to implement two phase flow in the ground with seeing the water body as fully saturated and i'm wondering if it maybe because of the materials i set for the water or because i have unrealistic BCs. Because i'm not sure how to define a realistic permeability for the waterbody. Right now i have porosity set to 0.9999 and permeability at 1E-6.
Are there any "good ways" to model an open water body in PorousFlow? Are there alternatives from another module?
Thanks in advance
@cpgr @WilkAndy

Hi,
Can you provide more information about what are you trying to do? Maybe a simple example if what you have so far may help.

Hi,
of course. I'm trying to model the thermal influence of an underground power cable on groundwater and open water bodies. My conceptual model looks like this:

I'm having a gradient from left to right. Right now i'm trying to implement two phase flow in the soil while seeing the water body as fully saturated. I'm running into problems with my water pressure on initialization. I'm using Water97FluidProperties but i get negative pressure values so the initilazation aborts. I'm not sure if it is because i use different dictators for the water body and the soil, my BCs or ICs or what exactly is the reason so i wondered if there maybe is another perhaps better or easier way to implement the water body.
I also added my current state.
Current_state.zip

I’ve never tried modeling something like this myself, but it does sound very interesting! If I were in your shoes, here’s how I’d approach debugging and simplifying the setup:
Start by removing the heat physics (temporarily) to focus only on the groundwater flow and saturation behavior. This might help you pinpoint whether the problem lies in the two-phase flow implementation or elsewhere.
Explore using MOOSE Transfer module and variable transfers at the boundaries between the water body and the soil.
Sometimes in multiphase simulations, where a phase has saturation zero wont converge in FE, try a FV implementation.
sorry I cant help,

node.title: strange perturbations in steady state time derivative solution
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I am investigating the following simple system equations:
${dX_V\over dt} = K_0$
${dX_I\over dt} = K_0$
These terms are a small part of a more complex system I am trying to inevitably solve. I attached this system at the bottom of this post for reference.
When I solve the above system and plot the concentration profile across my mesh, I have noticed that there are strange perturbations near the sides of the mesh. These perturbations seem to begin right at the first timestep and remain over time. The concentration does increase as a function of K0 over time, however this profile is puzzling because the expected result was for the concentrations (XV and XI) to be constant across the entire mesh. See the attached line scan picture for the first timestep, and input file below.
Could someone please advise how I might correct this behavior?
line scan across the mesh at time step 1

Input File
[Mesh] 
    [./gen]
        type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
        dim = 2
        nx = 50
        ny = 50
        xmax = 50 # nm
        ymax = 50 # nm
    [../]
[]

[Variables] 
    [./XV]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
    [./XI]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
    [../]  
[]

[ICs]
    [./XV_ic]
        type = ConstantIC
        variable = XV
        value = 1e-15 
    [../]
    [./XI_ic]
        type = ConstantIC
        variable = XI
        value = 1e-15
    [../]
[]

[Kernels]
    #################### Main Variable: XV ####################
    ## (𝜕𝑋𝑉)/𝜕𝑡 - 𝐾0 = 0
   
    [./timeXV] #(𝜕𝑋𝑉)/𝜕𝑡
        type = ADTimeDerivative
        variable = XV
    [../]
    [./defectgenV] #- 𝐾0
        type = ADMatBodyForce
        variable = XV
        material_property = K0 
    [../]

    #################### Main Variable: XI ####################
    ## (𝜕𝑋𝐼)/𝜕𝑡 -  𝐾0  = 0

    [./timeXI] #(𝜕𝑋𝐼)/𝜕𝑡
        type = ADTimeDerivative
        variable = XI
    [../]
    [./defectgenI] #- 𝐾0
        type = ADMatBodyForce
        variable = XI
        material_property = K0 
    [../]

[]


[Materials]

    [./SettingGeneralConstants]
        type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = 'K0'
        prop_values = '1.00e-05’
    [../]
       
[]


[Preconditioning]
    [my_prec]
      type = SMP
      full = true
    []
[]   


[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  l_max_its = 20 
  l_tol = 1e-12 
  nl_max_its = 15 
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-12 
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-12 
  end_time = 10  
  
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = ' hypre    boomeramg'

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1  # The default timestep size between solves
    cutback_factor = 0.5 
    growth_factor = 1.2 
    optimal_iterations = 7 
  [../]
[]


[Outputs]
    file_base = model
    [./exodus]
        type = Exodus
        print_linear_residuals = true
    [../]
[]

[Debug]
    show_var_residual_norms = true
[]


The more complex system I would like to eventually solve
This system relies on ∇X. Therefore, it is important that I remove the strange perturbations in concentration that is incorrectly being introduced above so that I can achieve a correct spatially resolved solution for this system.

Hello
Can you rescale the plot?
It looks to me like this is just numerical precision error of a constant solution. It would be good to see the amplitude of these oscillations to decide if they are relevant

Hi GiudGiud, thank you for looking into my question!
I have replotted and scaled the plot.
Ok these oscillations are likely irrelevant and nothing to worry about. They are to the order of 1e-16 or numerical precision (double precision by default in moose)
Thank you!

node.title: Difference in the pinning pressure results. MOOSE Vs. Analytical solutions

node.bodyText:
hello
is the spatial mesh converged?
Yes I used adaptive meshing. With refine value of 0.3

try a level of uniform refinement to make sure it's converged
(adding -r 1)

I understand the uniform refinement
[Mesh]
    type = GeneratedMesh
    dim = 2 # Problem dimension
    nx = 100 # Number of elements in the x-direction
    ny = 100 # Number of elements in the y-direction
    xmax = 100 # maximum x-coordinate of the mesh
    ymax = 100 # maximum y-coordinate of the mesh
    elem_type = QUAD4
    uniform_refine = 3 # Initial uniform refinement of the mesh
    parallel_type = DISTRIBUTED
[]

But I don't get
"(adding -r 1)"
Where I have to add? I am sorry for the stupid question.
-r 1 on the command line is the same as Mesh/uniform_refine=1

I think the mesh refinement is very fine.

Is it possible that we need to include some scaling factor to the MOOSE kernel as compared with the theoretical formulations. And how common is that?
because with the grain radius of 30, the driving pressure, Pd is
Pd = σ/R ,
σ is the interface energy (1.3333 in the present case).
So If I apply equal amount of pinning pressure, Pz,
(Pd - Pz=0, no Driving pressure for grain boundary movement), the grain should not shrink
here is what i am getting when I compared MOOSE results with Analytical model

I also checked with the FDM model and same evolution equation, the effect of pinning pressure is quite significant for the same values and comparable with the analytical model.

Yes, FDM shows more accurate results as compared with Analytical solutions (tested in MICRESS and home made code).
I am using
#dt = 1 #for constant time step
[TimeStepper] #for adaptive time steps
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    cutback_factor = 0.5
    dt = 0.1
    growth_factor = 1.2
    optimal_iterations = 12
[]

this is the time stepper not the time integrator.
if you did not specify a time integrator you are using 1st order implicit euler. you can try BDF2 to see if results improve.
Time integration accuracy might matter as well if you are not just looking for the steady state solution

yes I am using BDF2
[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    scheme = bdf2
    solve_type = PJFNK #Preconditioned JFNK (default)
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -pc_hypre_boomeramg_strong_threshold -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_nl -pc_hypre_boomeramg_agg_num_paths  -pc_hypre_boomeramg_max_levels  -pc_hypre_boomeramg_coarsen_type  -pc_hypre_boomeramg_interp_type  -pc_hypre_boomeramg_P_max  -pc_hypre_boomeramg_truncfactor'
    petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg  0.7 4 5 25 HMIS ext+i 2 0.3'
    steady_state_detection = true
    steady_state_start_time = 0
    steady_state_tolerance = 1e-8
    automatic_scaling = true
    compute_scaling_once = false
    use_pre_SMO_residual = false
    l_tol = 1.0e-3
    l_abs_tol = 1e-3
    l_max_its = 30
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-3
    nl_max_its = 30
    nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-3
    start_time = 0.0

this is really loose
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-3
    nl_max_its = 30
    nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-3

you need to tighten those criteria, the simulation results are not converged

node.title: How to find where the material derivative is defined

node.bodyText:
Hello
The declarePropertyDerivative are part of the DerivativeMaterialInterface base class.
It is a template for making these properties, that we instantiate here with the JvarMapKernelInterface<Kernel> class (itself a template instantiation)
Guillaume

And I can't find the JvarMapKernelInterface class file.

it's in a header as well, JvarMapInterface.h

where _dLdop is instantiated in which file

you can use grep to find that. See ACBulk.h or ACInterface.C

I can only find the relevant calls for _dLdop(getMaterialPropertyDerivative("mob_name", _var())) in ACBulk.h, but I cannot find the relevant content for _dLdop(declareMaterialPropertyDerivative("mob", _var.name())).The same situation occurs in ACInterface.C.
All related material calculations are in GBEvolution.C, and I couldn't find any.
if you find a simulation in the repository that uses this property, use Debug/show_material_props=true to see which Material declares it
The kernel ACinterface exists, but the material property _dLdop is not displayed. What's the situation?
dLdop is most likely created by the material creating L
